item.title: Report E-2024070553
item.description:
Report E-2024070553

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-25T15:13:18+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-16
  • City: MILTON
  • State: FL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On July 16, 2024, one (1) 5-gallon pail of UN2922 was punctured by a skid and released approximately less than one (<1) gallon of product to the loading dock floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from E3 Environmental (E3) to remediate the impacted site. E3 personnel utilized hand tools, absorbents, and a neutralizing agent to remediate the UN2922-impacted loading dock floor. All impacted material was collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum and staged on site.

item.title: Report E-2024070555
item.description:
Report E-2024070555

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-25T15:13:18+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-16
  • City: LAKELAND
  • State: FL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On July 16, 2024, one (1) 380-pound battery was damaged by a forklift and released approximately one (1) gallon of battery acid to the loading dock floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Hull's Environmental Services (HES) to remediate the impacted site. HES personnel utilized hand tools, absorbents, and a neutralizing agent to remediate the battery acid-impacted loading dock floor. All impacted material was collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum and staged on site. The damaged battery was wrapped in plastic sheeting and also staged on site

item.title: Report E-2024070391
item.description:
Report E-2024070391

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-19T18:15:23+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-11
  • City: LAKELAND
  • State: FL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On July 11, 2024, one (1) 55-gallon drum of UN3266 was punctured by a nail and released approximately two (2) cups of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Hull's Environmental Services (HES) to remediate the impacted site. HES personnel deployed soda ash to the UN3266-impacted trailer and swept them in with hand tools. All soda ash and the damaged drum were placed into one (1) 85-gallon drum for disposal.

Transportation by air has been confirmed.

item.title: Report I-2024060044
item.description:
Report I-2024060044

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-19T18:15:23+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-05-30
  • City: FORT MYERS
  • State: FL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: PEPSI BOTTLING COMPANY LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: According to the information obtained, the following occurred. While reversing into dock area at PepsiCo facility, vehicle struck another truck in lot, which damaged the saddle tank. Approximately 20 gallons of Diesel fuel were released to the asphalt surface and a minimal amount migrated to the nearby storm drain. PepsiCo personnel contained the release, and ACT Environmental was dispatched to perform the cleanup. Upon arrival on site, ACT Environmental applied absorbent material to the affected asphalt and inspected the nearby storm drain. Absorbent pads were utilized within storm drain catch basin to soak free product, and no further residual remained. Product was contained to the storm drain catch basin and did not migrate through drainage system. All spent absorbent material and pads were recovered and containerized into one 55-gallon drum, pending disposal in accordance with local, state, and federal regulations. There were no injuries or exposures reported.
